ripe 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
  • Get started

ripe

The goal of ripe is to create a more flexible way to rerun {magrittr} pipes.

Installation

remotes::install_github('yonicd/ripe')

Goal

We want to write the following in a shorter and more flexible way


f <- function(){
  
  stats::runif(20)%>%
    sample(10)%>%
    utils::head(5)
}

replicate(n=3,f(),simplify = FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.7597861 0.6900691 0.6002197 0.1192226 0.3555602
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.1832066 0.2396549 0.1332134 0.4384198 0.6737907
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.7479644 0.1039176 0.9291691 0.7845107 0.2970455

This is better!

stats::runif(20)%>%
  sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  ripe(replicate,n=4,simplify=FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.047568259 0.009610982 0.485226968 0.264670654 0.159910736
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.597557919 0.002913245 0.123754701 0.762221025 0.207973124
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.9642738 0.1708015 0.5218983 0.3227016 0.9399461
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] 0.4532350 0.3966742 0.0716835 0.9624202 0.6309057

Manipulate Chain Replicates

We can now manipulate the chain or move ripe around into different subsets of the chain, creating iterative replication workflows.


stats::runif(20)%>%
  #sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  ripe(replicate,n=4,simplify=FALSE)
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 0.1269561 0.9037062 0.8656164 0.6860040 0.7718242
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 0.24058149 0.47230597 0.97422795 0.01048445 0.53394971
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 0.1726116 0.1512779 0.4370591 0.8770037 0.3560740
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] 0.8110429 0.2801888 0.9517881 0.7308922 0.1690710

Convert Chains to Lazy Functions

You can also quickly convert the chain to a lazyeval function

f <- stats::runif(20)%>%
  sample(10)%>%
  utils::head(5)%>%
  lazy()

f()
#> [1] 0.15057076 0.06859179 0.41652781 0.99946027 0.69793552
f()
#> [1] 0.05353205 0.25852563 0.81598395 0.30461210 0.73838732
